docs.title: Home
docs.text:
Sydney Informatics Hub provides practical, hands-on training in bioinformatics and research computing for life science researchers. Our materials are developed for a national research audience in collaboration with Australian BioCommons.

All of our training emphasise reproucible workflows, best-practice tooling, and skills that can be applied directly to your research. These materials are used in workshops, short courses, and webinars delivered by SIH and our partners, and are designed to be reused, adapted, and extended.

Get in touch with us

SIH can also deliver training on request, including tailored or bespoke workshops. If you are interested in training delivery, bespoke materials, or reuse of these resources, please get in touch.

  • Bioinformatics training

    Explore our full catalogue of bioinformatics training materials from past workshops, covering topics from RNA-seq analysis to workflow development.

    View all training materials

  • Trainer resources

    Access our train-the-trainer resources to help you design, deliver, and adapt bioinformatics workshops for your own workshops.

    Browse trainer materials

  • Contribute

    Help improve these resources by suggesting changes, fixing issues, or contributing new content following our contribution guidelines.

    Read contribution guidelines

  • Code of conduct

    Learn about the standards of behaviour we expect from all participants, contributors, and trainers across our community.

    View the Code of Conduct

docs.title: Contribution guidelines
docs.text: This guide is for SIH staff maintaining the bioinformatics training catalogue.

docs.title: Before you start
docs.text:
1. Clone the repository if you haven't already: 

    git clone https://github.com/Sydney-Informatics-Hub/bioinformatics-training.git
cd bioinformatics-training

  2. Install dependencies:

pip3 install -r requirements.txt
  1. Create a branch for your changes:
git checkout -b your-branch-name

docs.title: Learner-facing materials
docs.text:
Edit docs/nextflow_courses.csv (or the relevant topic CSV file):

Add a new row with all required fields:

  • Topic: Category (e.g., Nextflow, RNA-seq, etc.)
  • Course: Course title
  • Description: Brief description of the course
  • Workshop materials: Link to workshop documentation
  • Repository: Link to code repository
  • Dataset: Link to training dataset
  • Webinar slides: Link to presentation slides
  • Webinar recording: Link to video recording

Use the correct formatting

  • Icons
  • Workshop materials: [:simple-readme:](url)
  • Repository: [:simple-github:](url)
  • Webinar slides: [:material-presentation:](url)
  • Webinar recording: [:simple-youtube:](url)

For empty cells, use a space: " " (not "" or blank, which renders as "nan")

docs.title: Trainer resources
docs.text:
Edit docs/assets/trainers.csv:

Add a new row with:

  • Course: Course title
  • Instructor notes: Link to instructor guide
  • Materials: Link to materials repository
  • Data: Link to data repository
  • Reference: Link to reference documentation
  • Maintainers: Name(s) of course maintainer(s)

docs.title: Testing your changes
docs.text:
Always test locally before pushing:

mkdocs serve

Then open http://127.0.0.1:8000 in your browser and verify:

  • ✓ Tables render correctly
  • ✓ No "nan" values appear in empty cells
  • ✓ All links work
  • ✓ Icons display properly
  • ✓ Formatting is consistent

docs.title: Submitting changes
docs.text:
1. Commit your changes: 

    git add .
git commit -m "Add [course name] to [learners/trainers] page"

  2. Push to GitHub: 

    git push origin your-branch-name

  3. Create a pull request on GitHub and request review from another team member

docs.title: CSV formatting
docs.text:
• Use consistent capitalization in course titles
  • Keep descriptions concise (1-2 sentences)
  • Always use spaces " " for empty cells
  • Test that all URLs are working before submitting

docs.title: Icons
docs.text:
• Only use the approved icon set
  • Always link icons to relevant resources: [:icon:](url) not just :icon:
  • Maintain consistency with existing entries

docs.title: Commit messages
docs.text:
• Use clear, descriptive commit messages
  • Format: Add/Update/Fix [what] for [course/page]
  • Examples:
  • Add Nextflow on HPC course to learners page
  • Update instructor notes for RNA-seq workshop
  • Fix broken link in trainers materials

docs.title: Documentation
docs.text:
• Update the README.md if you add new CSV files or change the structure
  • Document any new icons or conventions you introduce
  • Keep the contribution guidelines up to date

docs.title: Learners
docs.text:
This page brings together bioinformatics training materials developed by the Sydney Informatics Hub. These resources support researchers, students, and research support staff who use computational and data-intensive approaches in the life sciences.

The materials include hands-on workshops, short courses, and recorded webinars, and are designed to be practical and accessible. Our materials are focused on real research scenarios and suitable for learners from a range of backgrounds and experience levels. Many of these materials have been developed in collaboration with partner organisations: Australian BioCommons, QCIF, NCI, Pawsey Supercomputing Research Center, UNSW Structural Biology Facility, Monash Bioinformatics Platform, and Seqera.

If you have questions about suitability, access, or training opportunities, please contact us.

Topic Course Description Workshop Dataset Slides Webinar Bioinformatics What exactly is bioinformatics? Introduction to bioinformatics experiments Genomics Getting started with germline genomics Introduction to germline mapping and variant calling Transcriptomics Getting started with RNAseq Introduction to differential expression analysis with bulk RNAseq data Transcriptomics Getting started with spatial omics Introduction to spatial transcriptomics Functional enrichment Making sense of gene lists with FEA Introduction to functional enrichment analysis Structural biology Protein structure prediction Introduction to structural prediction with tools like Alphafold Pipelines Nextflow for the Life Sciences Introduction to building and runing Nextflow pipelines Pipelines Nextflow on HPC Configure and run Nextflow pipelines on HPC Pipelines Configuring nf-core Configure nf-core pipelines for your needs HPC Scaling your workflows to HPC Foundational concepts of HPC as they relate to bioinformatics HPC Introduction to NCI Gadi Quick start guide for using NCI's Gadi HPC HPC Where to go when your bioinformatics outgrows your compute Explainer of national computational infrastructure for bioinformatics

docs.title: Trainers
docs.text:
Resources to run your own workshop. To get started, please view the Instructor notes for the relevant course.
